than in the PI due to additional industrial emissions that are not
present in the PI. Similarly to North America, European
industrial BC emissions have been decreasing signi
. In Fig. 2 we account for this known change by increasing
the global aerosol model PD concentrations of BC by a factor of
2.0 ± 0.5 (see Methods). The global aerosol model with AeroCom
re emissions results in a PD/PI BC ratio, at the altitude of the
measurement site, that is a factor 4.1 (3.1
PI BC ratio recorded in the ice core; again, consistent with
AeroCom PI emissions being too low. Using CMIP6 emissions
results in a PD/PI ratio that is a factor of 2.7 (2.0
re emissions results in a PD/PI BC ratio that is a factor
2.2) lower than the ratio recorded in the ice core, while
using SIMFIRE-BLAZE emissions results in a PD/PI BC ratio that
1.6) higher than the ratio recorded in the ice core.
Due to the short atmospheric lifetimes of aerosol and soluble
gases, ice cores store local-to-hemispheric-scale changes and
contain many uncertainties as a proxy for
nd that the changes in BC recorded
in ice cores at four sites in very different environments are
cantly lower in the PI than in the PD, especially over
North America and Europe. Compared to using
within the aerosol model results in closer agreement with the
measured PD/PI ratio of total BC.
re occurrence and emissions provide further evidence for the
re occurrence from the PI to the PD. Arora and
recently reported a 28% decline in global burned area
change to PD estimates of burned area from GFED4s (~475 Mha)
results in an estimated PI range in
burned area from 679 to 1040 Mha (Supplementary Table 3).
Emissions from SIMFIRE-BLAZE in the PI are based on a burned
area of 641 Mha, while emissions from LM
burned area of 1180 Mha (Supplementary Figure 3). This would
suggest that burned area in SIMFIRE-BLAZE is below the lower
end of the range in PI burned area and LM
end of the range. However, Arora and Melton state that their
burned area estimates do not include contributions from agri-
cultural burning, which are a signi
plausible upper limit of PI emissions in many regions. A regional
comparison of modelled burned area with the Arora and Melton
suggests that the distribution of burned area, and hence
re is appropriate, although the magnitude of
The charcoal record (see Supplementary Figure 2) suggests that
re occurrence in the tropics (30° S to 30° N) increased slightly
from the PI to the PD. Moreover, in general agreement with
re occurrence in the extra-tropical regions (>30° S and N)
in the PI was similar to or larger than in the year 2000
re occurrence in the NH mid-latitude
45° N) is lower in the PD compared to the PI, due
mainly to a decrease in charcoal deposition occurring over the last
few decades, the same region in which the
predict the largest decrease in PD emissions compared to the PI,
western North America also suggests a very rapid decline in
occurrence from the PI to the PD

res are also consistent with a decrease in
PI (see Supplementary Figure 1 and Supplementary Table 1). We
note that CO measurements in Antarctic ice cores
re emissions are higher over the Southern Hemisphere
than are currently estimated in inventories. Although the
measured quadrupling of the enhancement in PI CO from

re emission inventory does not capture
the trends in these proxies, which are more closely in agreement
model outperforms the other in all regions and each has its own
strengths (see Methods). Based on currently available measure-
ments and the limited comparison with ice core records, we
re represents what is likely to be an upper limit
to the plausible range of PI
mean PI cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) concentrations
simulated by the aerosol model for the four
narios (see Methods). Global monthly mean PI CCN con-
centrations at 915 hPa (approximately low-level warm cloud
when using CMIP6 emissions; this is a factor
of 1.1 higher than those calculated using AeroCom emissions.
Compared to using CMIP6 emissions, CCN concentrations are a
factor of 1.3 higher when using SIMFIRE-BLAZE emissions and a
tary Figure 6). Over continental regions, the increases in CCN
concentrations are even greater relative to using the CMIP6
emissions, a factor of 1.5 higher using SIMFIRE-BLAZE emis-
sions and a factor of 2.1 higher using LM
portion of this difference is due to substantially increased
emissions in the NH mid-latitudes (Fig. 1). In general, using
CMIP6 emissions results in increases in CCN concentrations in
all regions compared to using AeroCom emissions, the exceptions
being near the high PD deforestation regions of Brazil and both
polar regions. Over Africa, CCN concentrations are higher in
extra-tropical regions but lower in tropical regions when incor-
CMIP6. Over Indonesia and northern Australia CCN con-
centrations are higher when incorporating LM
compared to using CMIP6 emissions, while using SIMFIRE-
BLAZE emissions yields lower CCN concentrations. Downwind
of southern Australia and Patagonia both
datasets lead to higher CCN concentrations than when using
re emissions, but similar or lower CCN concentrations
are calculated over most of the Southern Ocean when using the
re models. Incorporating SIMFIRE-BLAZE and LM
emissions results in marine CCN concentrations that are 1.2
times higher than when using CMIP6 emissions, due to long-
range aerosol transport. The current study shows that pre-
re emissions cause larger uncertainty in CCN (and
hence pre-industrial to present-day aerosol indirect forcing) than
the combined estimate in Hamilton et al.
parameters related to aerosol processes and emissions.
Effect on PI to PD anthropogenic aerosol radiative forcing
Changes in PI CCN concentrations alter both the size and
number of cloud drops in the PI, and therefore the magnitude of
